did.abstract: The Arena Stage records consists of material that span the theater's 60 year history including production notebooks, photographs, audiotapes, videotpaes, playbills, scrapbooks, scripts, handwritten correspondence, and other production materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Arena Stage records, Collection #C0017, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Special Collections and Archives staff. EAD markup completed by Jordan Patty in 2011.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Arena Stage was an early leader in the resident theater movement. One of the first not-for-profit theaters in the United States as well as a pioneer of the regional theater movement the Arena Stage was the first regional theater to transfer a production to Broadway, the first invited by the U.S. State Department to tour behind the Iron Curtain and the first to receive a Tony Award. Co-founded in 1950 by Edward Mangum a teacher from the George Washington University, and Zelda Fichandler, one of his students, Arena Stage was opened in Washington D.C. to fill the void left by the closing of the National Theater in 1948. Deriving it's name from the idea of "theater in the round," Arena Stage became one of the first resident theaters in the United States, beginning with a company of only eight actors. Today, Arena performs to over 250,000 patrons during a September to June season and employs nearly 200 theater professionals and craftpersons, who are responsible for all the costumes and scenery seen on stage. Many now- famous actors took part in Arena Stage productions during the early part of their careers. Some of them include Robert Prosky, Morgan Freeman, Dianne Weist, James Earl Jones, Kevin Kline, Christopher Guest, Yeardly Smith and Samuel L. Jackson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Arena Stage records consists of material that span the theater's 60 year history including production notebooks, photographs, audiotapes, videotpaes, playbills, scrapbooks, scripts, handwritten correspondence, and other production materials.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Special Collections and Archives holds other theatre collections.

scopecontent.p: Consists of literary materials for plays, review packets, newspaper clippings and photocopies, press releases, and wrap files. The wrap files consist largely of publicity materials (press releases, opening night/press night invitations, programs, review packets, background information, radio ad copy, group sales materials, and similar), in folders as listed.

did.unittitle: 1. File - "Yerma, by Federico Garcia Lorca, trans. By W.S. Merwin, Oct. 4-Nov. 24, 1991" - folders ("Yerma - Salvador Dali," "Yerma - Visual Images"); poems-on-tape; packets of images, articles, etc

2. File - "Yerma, by Federico Garcia Lorca, trans. By W.S. Merwin, Oct. 4-Nov. 24, 1991" - folders ("Yerma - Production History," "Yerma - Critical Essay," "Yerma - Lorca's Life," "Yerma - Critical Essay") - articles/essays

3. File - "Caucasian Chalk Circle, by Bertolt Brecht, trans. by Ralph Manheim, 1990-91 Season" - folders ("Caucasian Chalk Circle," "Living Stage Articles [mislabeled - actually contains essay on CCC], unlabeled) - articles, essays, programs, scores, etc

4. File - "Born Guilty, stage adaptation by Ari Roth, 1990-91 season" - folders ("Contemporary German Society and the Implications of Unification," "Miscellaneous," "Art, Academics, and the Nazi Past," "The Right Wing and Neo Nazis in Germany Today," "The Controversy Over Philipp Jenninger's Speech," "Commemorating the Nazi Past") - articles, essays, rights negotiations, etc
5. File - "The Seagull, 1990-91, Directed by Zelda Finchandler" - scripts w/notes, scores, programs, articles, etc
6. File - "Before It Hits Home, by Cheryl West, 1990-91 Season" - folders (both labeled "Before It Hits Home") - script, magazines, articles (largely on AIDS)
7. File - "My Children! My Africa!, by Athol Fugard, 1990-91 Season" - largely articles (on South Africa, apartheid, and playwright)
8. File - "Cerceau, by Viktor Slavkin, translated by Fritz Bun + Lawrence Maslon, 1990-91 Season" - scripts, scores, articles, magazines, etc

scopecontent.p: Acc. 2008-004 consists of Zelda Fichandler speeches, files, Living Stage documents, correspondence, red books, and scripts. Hard copy inventory in Arena Stage accession folder. Acc. 2010-003 consists of 1 box of files, correspondence, speeches, scripts, and some photographs. Also includes extensive material on Awake and Sing, and the speeches date from 1968 until 2004.
An electronic box inventory is unavailable. Please contact speccoll@gmu.edu for more information.

9 boxes of research packets from plays that also include various script drafts, some by Sarah Ruhl. Some folders also contain correspondence. File folders and loose materials were removed from larger brown folders with photocopy of discarded brown folder labels. Audiovisual and electronic records removed from paper records and placed in separate document box. Separation sheets identify original location.
